tn.text: This can mean 1) "I have heard people talk about what you have done" or 2) "I heard what you just said."
"bring your work back to life" or "do again what you did before"
" make your work known"
Habakkuk continues to describe his vision of Yahweh.
These are the lines of light that come from light sources such as the sun.
Yahweh's
Habakkuk continues to describe his vision of Yahweh.
This can mean 1) he surveyed it the way a conqueror would before assigning portions to his governors or 2) he made it shake.

"mountains that have existed since the beginning of time ... hills that will exist until the end of time." If your language has no different words for "hills" and "mountains" or for "eternal" and "everlasting," you can combine them as the ULB did.
in worship to God. "were flattened to the ground" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
Habakkuk continues to describe his vision of Yahweh.

tn.ref: the tents of Cushan in affliction, and the fabric of the tents ... of Midian trembling
tn.text: The people of Midian and Cushan who tremble or shake with fear are like tent cloth that moves when the wind blows. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This can be 1) the name of a people group otherwise unknown or 2) the same as Cush. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

tn.ref: Was Yahweh angry at the rivers? Was your wrath against the rivers, or your fury against the sea ... victorious chariots?
tn.text: If your language does not have separate words for "angry" and "wrath" and "fury," you can combine the lines: "Was Yahweh angry with the rivers? Was your fury against the sea ... victorious chariots?" AT: "Yahweh was not angry with the rivers. Your wrath was not against the rivers, nor was your fury against the sea ... victorious chariots." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: you rode upon your horses and your victorious chariots
tn.text: As a soldier would ride a horse or a chariot into battle, Yahweh came to save the people of Israel.
This term means "stop and reflect" or "lift up, exalt." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

tn.ref: The mountains saw you and twisted in pain
tn.text: As God divided the earth, the mountains moved, as if they could see God's actions and react by turning away from where the earth was divided. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: the deep sea raised a shout!
tn.text: the sound of large waves in the sea
water levels rise
Habakkuk continues to describe his vision of Yahweh.

tn.ref: at the light of your arrows
tn.text: because the light of Yahweh's arrows was so bright

tn.ref: You have marched over the earth with indignation. In wrath you have threshed the nations.
tn.text: These two sentences share similar meanings. Together they refer to Yahweh punishing the nations for their wickedness. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
anger at something that is wrong
Habakkuk describes Yahweh.
This can also mean "your Messiah," but the reference is clearly to "your people," so use a common noun here, not as a proper name.

tn.ref: You shatter the head of the house of the wicked
tn.text: "You completely destroy the leader of the wicked people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Habakkuk describes Yahweh destroying the Chaldeans.
The power and quickness of the Chaldeans as they attacked the people of Israel is compared to the coming of a sudden storm. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"bragging"

tn.ref: devours the poor in a hiding place
tn.text: finds poor people who are hiding from them and kills them and takes all their goods (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
eats everything quickly
Habakkuk describes his fear when he thinks about how Yahweh would punish the Chaldeans.

tn.ref: my inner parts trembled! My lips quivered ... Decay comes into my bones ... under myself I tremble
tn.text: These refer to fear caused by thinking about future events. Habakkuk uses several parts of his body to express that every part of him is afraid. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
rot

tn.ref: fig tree ... vines ... olive tree ... fields ... flock ... cattle
tn.text: there is no food. These are almost all the sources of food to be found in the land of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
Habakkuk praises Yahweh.
Both words mean "be joyful," but if your language has a special word for rejoicing after winning a battle, use that "exult" here.

tn.ref: makes my feet like the deer's; he leads me upon my high places
tn.text: Feet like a deer would give Habakkuk the ability to climb steep rocky cliffs. The words "high places" refer to places out of the reach of danger. He is saying God is giving him the ability to find a place of safety. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
